title: 115_hr1865
content: The Act titled "Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act of 2017" clarifies that Section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934 was not meant to protect websites promoting prostitution or facilitating sex trafficking. Congress believes websites allowing the sale of sex trafficking victims need clarification to prevent such protection. SEC. 3. PROMOTION OF PROSTITUTION AND RECKLESS DISREGARD OF SEX TRAFFICKING. This section amends Chapter 117 of title 18, United States Code, by adding a new provision that targets individuals using interstate commerce to promote or facilitate prostitution, with penalties of fines and imprisonment for up to 10 years. The new provision in Chapter 117 of title 18, United States Code targets individuals using interstate commerce to promote or facilitate prostitution. Those who promote or facilitate the prostitution of 5 or more persons, or act in reckless disregard of contributing to sex trafficking, may face fines, imprisonment for up to 25 years, or both. Additionally, individuals injured by a violation of this provision may seek damages and attorneys' fees in a United States district court. The new provision in Chapter 117 of title 18, United States Code mandates mandatory restitution for violations of promoting or facilitating prostitution. An affirmative defense is available if the defendant can prove that the promotion or facilitation of prostitution is legal in the targeted jurisdiction. SEC. 4. ENSURING ABILITY TO ENFORCE FEDERAL AND STATE CRIMINAL AND CIVIL LAW RELATING TO SEX TRAFFICKING. This section amends the Communications Act of 1934 to clarify that it does not limit the enforcement of sex trafficking laws in civil actions or criminal prosecutions under State or Federal law. The amendment ensures federal liability for publishing information or facilitating sex trafficking under section 1591 of title 18, United States Code. The effective date of the amendments is upon enactment, regardless of when the alleged conduct occurred. Section 1591(e) of title 18, United States Code is amended to define "participation in a venture" as knowingly assisting in a violation of subsection (a)(1). State Attorneys General are granted the authority to bring civil actions against individuals who violate section 1591 on behalf of the residents of their state. Section 1595 of title 18, United States Code is amended for technical and conforming adjustments. The Act and its amendments do not limit or preempt any civil or criminal actions under Federal or State law. Additionally, a GAO study is mandated. SEC. 8. GAO STUDY. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study 3 years after the enactment of this Act, providing information on civil actions under section 2421A(c) of title 18, United States Code, that resulted in damages awarded. Information on civil actions under section 2421A(c) of title 18, United States Code that did not result in damages awarded, including amount claimed, nature of losses, and reason for dismissal. Also, details on restitution orders under section 2421A(d), such as defendant type, requested amount by the Government, and court-ordered amount. For defendants convicted of violating section 2421A(b) of title 18, United States Code, information on whether restitution was ordered, defendant type (corporation or individual), amount requested by the Government, and reasons for not ordering restitution.
